paragraph.text: Each employee shall furnish to the employer proof that the employee has voted or attempted to vote.
The proof that an employee has voted or attempted to vote shall be on a form prescribed by the State Board.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board of canvassers” means the local board of elections in a county after the local board organizes itself for the purpose of canvassing the vote after an election in that county.

paragraph.text: “Canvass” means the entire process of vote tallying, vote tabulation, and vote verification or audit, culminating in the production and certification of the official election results.
For absentee ballots, the “canvass” includes the opening of any envelope accompanying an absentee ballot and the assembly and review of absentee ballots in preparation for vote tallying.

For provisional ballots, the “canvass” includes the review of the provisional ballot applications described in § 11-303 of this title and the assembly and review of provisional ballots in preparation for vote tallying.

subsection.text: “Counting center” means one or more central locations designated by a local board to conduct the canvass.
“Removable data storage device” means a read-only memory device that is programmed to record votes as they are cast on an electronic voting system.

paragraph.text: “Unofficial returns” means a vote tabulation reported on election night after the polls close.
“Unofficial returns” does not include the absentee ballot count or the provisional ballot count.

subsection.text: “Vote tabulation” or “vote counting” means the aggregation of the votes cast by individual voters to produce vote totals at any level.
“Vote tallying” means the recording of votes cast by individual voters on a certified voting system whether done by:

paragraph.text: a mechanical lever voting machine;
an electronic voting device; or
making marks manually on a tally sheet.

section.text: The State Board shall adopt regulations consistent with the provisions of this title governing the canvass.

paragraph.text: Each qualified voter present at the polls at 8 p.m. on election day shall be allowed to vote before the election judges commence their duties under this section.

In accordance with the provisions of this article and regulations adopted by the State Board, after the last voter has voted in an election, the election judges shall follow the instructions issued by the election director for closing the polls and for performing the tasks required in the postclosing period.

subsection.text: In accordance with this section, the election judges shall:

paragraph.text: secure the voting system to prevent further voting;
if appropriate to the voting system, record the vote, produce vote totals for the polling place, and announce results to those present;
complete all documents, records, and reports required by law or regulation after the closing of the polls;
perform any other tasks assigned by the election director;
assemble and account for materials to be returned to the local board, including, if applicable for the voting system used in that election:

subparagraph.text: removable data storage devices from voting equipment;
voted ballots;
precinct registers;
voting authority cards;
signs and posters;
records, reports, logs, affidavits, certificates, and other documents;
keys to voting devices;
poll books; and
any other materials specified by the election director;

paragraph.text: assure that equipment and materials left in the polling place for retrieval at a later time are stored in a secure manner; and
deliver materials and equipment to the local board and obtain receipts from the board certifying the delivery of the items.

subsection.text: Judges may be observed, while performing their duties under this section, until they have finished their work and leave the premises by:

paragraph.text: authorized challengers, watchers, and observers in accordance with § 10-311 of this article;
any candidate; and
any other person lawfully present.

subsection.text: A board of canvassers shall:

paragraph.text: convene at the designated counting center for that county on or before the day of the election, but not later than 5 p.m. on that day, and be sworn in;
meet only in public session; and

subject to regulations adopted by the State Board to ensure the integrity of the electoral process and that the accuracy of the vote tabulation is not impeded or compromised, provide for observation and understanding of the canvass by those individuals in attendance.

subsection.text: Each board of canvassers shall elect by majority vote a chairman and secretary from among its members.

Each member of the board of canvassers shall take an oath, administered and recorded by the clerk of the circuit court, to canvass and declare the votes cast truthfully and to perform other duties required by law.

paragraph.text: At the first meeting of the board of canvassers for the purpose of canvassing, a majority of the whole board of canvassers shall be a quorum.
If a quorum is not present, the members present shall adjourn until the next day.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this article, all decisions shall be reached by a majority vote of the members present.
If a member is not present at the scheduled time for vote canvassing, a substitute member of the board of canvassers may be sworn in.
At least one member of the board of canvassers present shall be a registered voter of the principal minority party.
Once the board has satisfied the requirements of subsections (a) through (g) of this section, it may proceed with the canvass in accordance with the regulations of the State Board.

Following an election, each local board shall meet at its designated counting center to canvass the absentee ballots cast in that election in accordance with the regulations and guidelines established by the State Board.

paragraph.text: A local board may not open any envelope of an absentee ballot prior to 8 a.m. on the Wednesday following election day.
A local board may not delay the commencement of the canvass to await the receipt of late-arriving, timely absentee ballots.
An absentee ballot shall be deemed timely received if it is received in accordance with the regulations and guidelines established by the State Board.
An absentee ballot that is received after the deadline specified by the regulations and guidelines may not be counted.

The State Board shall adopt regulations that reflect the policy that the clarity of the intent of the voter is the overriding consideration in determining the validity of an absentee ballot or the vote cast in a particular contest.
A local board may not reject an absentee ballot except by unanimous vote and in accordance with regulations of the State Board.
The local board shall reject an absentee ballot if:

subparagraph.text: before the ballot is canvassed, the local board determines that the voter died before election day;
the voter failed to sign the oath on the ballot envelope;
the local board received more than one ballot from the same individual for the same election in the same ballot envelope; or
the local board determines that an absentee ballot is intentionally marked with an identifying mark that is clearly evident and placed on the ballot for the purpose of identifying the ballot.

paragraph.text: If the local board receives more than one legally sufficient ballot, in separate envelopes, from the same individual, the local board shall:

subparagraph.text: count only the ballot with the latest properly signed oath; and
reject any other ballot.

paragraph.text: If the intent of the voter is not clearly demonstrated, the local board shall reject only the vote for that office or question.
If an absentee voter casts a vote for an individual who has ceased to be a candidate, the vote for that candidate may not be counted, but that vote does not invalidate the remainder of the ballot.

subsection.text: Following an election, each local board shall meet at its designated counting center to canvass the provisional ballots cast in that election in accordance with the regulations and guidelines established by the State Board.
A local board may not open an envelope of a provisional ballot until the local board has approved the provisional ballot application.
The State Board shall adopt regulations to implement this section.

paragraph.text: A local board may not reject a provisional ballot except by unanimous vote and in accordance with regulations of the State Board.
The local board shall reject a provisional ballot if:

subparagraph.text: pursuant to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the local board determines that the individual who cast the provisional ballot is not qualified to vote that provisional ballot;
the individual failed to sign the oath on the provisional ballot application;
the individual cast more than one ballot for the same election; or
the local board determines that a provisional ballot is intentionally marked with an identifying mark that is clearly evident and placed on the ballot for the purpose of identifying the ballot.

paragraph.text: If the intent of the voter with respect to a particular contest is not clearly demonstrated, the local board shall reject only the vote for that contest.
For the purposes of this section, an individual is qualified to vote the provisional ballot cast if the local board determines that:

subparagraph.text: the individual is registered in the State;

if the provisional ballot was cast because the voter failed to provide required identification, the individual who cast the provisional ballot has met the identification requirements established by the State Board; and
if the provisional ballot was cast during a period covered by a court order or other order extending the time for closing the polls, the order has not been invalidated by a subsequent court order.

subsection.text: A local board shall count:

paragraph.text: the entire provisional ballot if the address on the provisional ballot application is within the precinct where the provisional ballot was cast; or
only the votes cast by the voter for each candidate or question applicable to the precinct in which the voter resides, as determined by the address on the provisional ballot application of the voter.

The State Board shall ensure the establishment of a system that any individual who casts a provisional ballot may access without cost to discover whether the ballot was counted and, if not counted, the reason it was not.
The system established under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall ensure the confidentiality of the individual who accesses the system and the secrecy of each ballot.

subsection.text: A candidate or absentee voter aggrieved by the decision of a local board to reject, or not to reject, an absentee ballot shall have the right of appeal to the circuit court for the county.
The appeal must be filed within 5 days from the date of the completion of the official canvass by the board of all the votes cast at the election.
The appeal shall be heard de novo, without a jury, as soon as possible.

paragraph.text: The decision of the circuit court may be appealed to the Court of Special Appeals, provided the appeal is taken within 48 hours from the entry of the decision of the circuit court.
The appeal shall be heard and decided on the original papers, including a written transcript of the testimony taken in the case.
The original papers and the transcript shall be transmitted to the Court of Special Appeals within 5 days from the taking of the appeal, and the appeal shall be heard as soon as possible.

section.text: Any person who asserts that an election official has violated the provisions of this article relating to provisional ballots may file an administrative complaint under procedures established by the State Board.
The person designated to maintain custody of the documents and records required under this title shall maintain and secure those items in accordance with the regulations adopted by the State Board.

subsection.text: If a board of canvassers determines that there appears to be an error in the documents or records produced at the polling place following an election, then it immediately shall investigate the matter to ascertain whether the records or documents are correct.
The board of canvassers may correct a document or record only in accordance with the regulations of the State Board.

Within 10 days after any election, and before certifying the results of the election, each board of canvassers shall verify the vote count in accordance with the regulations prescribed by the State Board for the voting system used in that election.
Upon completion of the verification process, the members of the board of canvassers shall:

paragraph.text: certify in writing that the election results are accurate and that the vote has been verified; and
provide copies of the election results to the persons specified under § 11-401 of this title.

If a member of a board of canvassers dissents from a determination of an election result or reasonably believes that the conduct of a local board member or local board proceeding was not in compliance with applicable law or regulation or was otherwise illegal or irregular, the member shall prepare and file with the local board a distinct written statement of the reasons for the dissent or concern.
The State Board shall maintain a file of the written statements submitted under this subsection by members of the local boards.

After each election, each board of canvassers shall transmit one certified copy of the election results in its county, attested by the signatures of the chairperson and secretary of the board of canvassers, to:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the State Board; and
the clerk of the circuit court for the appropriate county.

paragraph.text: The statement may be mailed or delivered in person.

subsection.text: After each general election in which votes have been cast for a write-in candidate, each board of canvassers shall transmit a statement of returns of the votes cast for write-in candidates who have filed a certificate of candidacy.

paragraph.text: The transmittal shall be made on the second Friday after a primary or general election or, if the canvass is completed after that date, within 48 hours after the completion of the canvass.

subparagraph.text: Except as specified in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, after a special primary or special election, the transmittal shall be made as soon as possible, but no later than the second Thursday after the election.
After a special primary or special election that is held at the same time as a primary or general election, the transmittal shall be made in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The clerk of the circuit court shall record the election results filed with the court under this section.

Unless otherwise provided by the Maryland Constitution, and except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each board of canvassers shall prepare a statement of election results by precinct for each candidate or question voted on at the election and declare:

paragraph.text: who is elected or nominated for office:

subparagraph.text: in county government; or
for any other office voted for only within that county, if the certificate of candidacy for that office was issued by the local board; and

paragraph.text: whether or not a question is adopted or approved.

subsection.text: The statement prepared by the board of canvassers under this section may not report the absentee vote separately by precinct.
Each local board shall publish a sufficient number of copies of the complete election results, tabulated by precinct, and shall make the copies available to the public at cost.

paragraph.text: In addition to the statement of election results specified under subsection (a) of this section, the State Board shall make available in an electronic format a report of election results for each candidate or question voted on at the election:

subparagraph.text: by precinct;
by State legislative district, including any subdistrict;
by county legislative district; and
for each county as a whole.

paragraph.text: The State Board may make the report specified under paragraph (1) of this subsection available to the public at cost.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Board, the equipment and documentation of a voting system, including all paper and electronic documentation, shall remain secured following the verification required by § 11-306 of this title until:

subparagraph.text: the expiration of the period allowed for initiating a recount;
in the event of a recount, the recount is completed; and
the resolution of any election contest.

paragraph.text: After the expiration of the period specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the equipment and documentation of the voting system shall be maintained in accordance with regulations of the State Board.

subsection.text: A voting system may be opened and the documents and equipment associated with it examined in the presence of the officer having custody of the voting system upon:

paragraph.text: the order of any court of competent jurisdiction; or
the direction of any legislative committee charged with investigating a contested election affected by the use of the voting system.

subsection.text: Following each gubernatorial primary or special primary election to fill a vacancy in the office of Representative in Congress, the State Board shall:

paragraph.text: convene within 2 days after the certified official election results are received from the local boards;
if a majority of the members of the State Board is not present, adjourn for not more than 1 day;
determine which candidates, by the greatest number of votes, have been nominated to each office and which questions have received a sufficient number of votes to be adopted or approved; and
prepare and certify statewide election results based on the certified copies of the statements made by the boards of canvassers.

If a member of the State Board dissents from a determination of an election result or reasonably believes that the conduct of a Board member or Board proceeding was not in compliance with applicable law or regulation or was otherwise illegal or irregular, the member shall prepare and file with the Board a distinct written statement of the reasons for the dissent or concern.
The State Board shall maintain a file of the written statements submitted under this subsection by members of the Board.

subsection.text: The Board of State Canvassers consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of State;
the Comptroller;
the State Treasurer;
the Clerk of the Court of Appeals; and
the Attorney General.

subsection.text: Three members of the Board of State Canvassers constitute a quorum.
The State Administrator of the State Board of Elections serves as secretary to the Board of State Canvassers.
The State Treasurer may appoint, as the Treasurer’s designee, a deputy treasurer to serve on the Board of State Canvassers.
The Board of State Canvassers shall:

subparagraph.text: convene only after a presidential primary election, a State general election, or a general or special general election that includes a candidate for member of the Congress of the United States;
convene within 35 days of that election; and
if a majority of members of the Board of State Canvassers is not present, adjourn for not more than 1 day;

paragraph.text: determine which candidates, by the greatest number of votes, have been elected to each office and which questions have received a sufficient number of votes to be adopted or approved;
prepare statewide election results for each candidate and question, based on the certified copies of the statements made by the boards of canvassers; and
prepare and transmit a certified statement of the election results to the State Board of Elections.

If a member of the Board of State Canvassers dissents from a determination of an election result or reasonably believes that the conduct of a Board member or Board proceeding was not in compliance with applicable law or regulation or was otherwise illegal or irregular, the member shall prepare and transmit a distinct written statement of the reasons for the dissent or concern to the State Board of Elections.
The State Board of Elections shall maintain a file of the written statements submitted under this subsection by members of the Board of State Canvassers.

subsection.text: On receipt, in accordance with this subtitle, of the returns of an election for electors to choose a President and Vice President of the United States or of an election to choose a member of Congress, the Governor shall:

paragraph.text: ascertain and enumerate the number of votes cast for each candidate for President and Vice President of the United States and declare elected the presidential electors of the candidates who receive the highest number of votes; and
in each contest, ascertain and enumerate the number of votes cast for each candidate voted for as a member of Congress and declare elected the candidate who receives the highest number of votes.

subsection.text: After ascertaining and enumerating the number of votes for candidates as required by subsection (a) of this section, the Governor shall:

paragraph.text: sign and issue a proclamation declaring the name of each candidate who is elected; and
cause the proclamation to be published in newspapers.

section.text: The Governor shall issue a commission to an individual elected to or continued in office only if the individual’s election is certified by the State Board.

subsection.text: The State Board shall certify election results in accordance with the provisions of this article and regulations adopted by the State Board.
The State Board shall:

paragraph.text: promptly deliver under its seal a certified statement notifying:

subparagraph.text: each individual who is declared elected;
each individual who is continued in office;
the Secretary and presiding officer of the United States Senate, in the case of the election of a United States Senator to represent the State; and
the Clerk and presiding officer of the United States House of Representatives, in the case of the election of a member of the House of Representatives to represent the State; and

paragraph.text: publish a sufficient number of copies of the certified statements of the votes cast throughout the State that are delivered to it by the Board of State Canvassers and make the copies available to the public at cost.

section.text: A certificate issued by the State Board to the Secretary and presiding officer of the United States Senate or to the Clerk and presiding officer of the House of Representatives of the United States under § 11–603(b)(1)(iii) and (iv) of this subtitle constitutes prima facie evidence of the right of the individual certified to be seated for office in the United States Congress.

subsection.text: In a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision in which a referendum vote is held on a law, ordinance, or resolution, the executive head of the county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision promptly shall report the results of the referendum to the clerk of the court for the county.
As promptly as possible thereafter, the clerk of the court shall certify the results of the referendum to the State Board.

A candidate for public or party office who has been defeated based on the certified results of any election conducted under this article may petition for a recount of the votes cast for the office sought.
The petition shall specify that the recount be conducted:

paragraph.text: in all of the precincts in which the office was on the ballot; or
only in the precincts designated in the petition.

subsection.text: The petition shall be filed with the board with which the candidate’s certificate of candidacy was filed.
The petition must be filed within 3 days after the results of the election have been certified.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall promptly notify each appropriate local board of a petition that is filed with the State Board.
A local board shall promptly notify the State Board of a petition that is filed with the local board.

subsection.text: An opposing candidate of the petitioner under § 12-101 of this subtitle may file a counterpetition if:

paragraph.text: the petition filed under § 12-101 of this subtitle did not specify all of the precincts in which the office was on the ballot; and
on completion of the recount, the winner of the election is changed.

subsection.text: A counterpetition shall be a request for a recount of the votes for the office in the precincts not specified by the petitioner under § 12-101 of this subtitle.
The opposing candidate shall file the counterpetition with the board with which the candidate’s certificate of candidacy was filed.
The petition must be filed within 2 days of the determination under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall promptly notify each appropriate local board of a counterpetition that is filed with the State Board.
A local board shall promptly notify the State Board of a counterpetition that is filed with the local board.

subsection.text: A petition for a recount based on the certified results of a question on the ballot in an election conducted under this article may be filed by a registered voter eligible to vote for that question.
The petition shall specify that the recount be conducted:

paragraph.text: in all of the precincts in which the office was on the ballot; or
only in precincts designated in the petition.
If the question was on the ballot in one county, the petition shall be filed in that county.
If the question was on the ballot in more than one county, the petition shall be filed with the State Board.

subsection.text: The petition must be filed within 2 days after the results of the election are certified.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall promptly notify each appropriate local board of a petition that is filed with the State Board.
A local board shall promptly notify the State Board of a petition that is filed with the local board.

subsection.text: A counterpetition to a question filed under § 12-103 of this subtitle may be filed by a voter eligible to vote for that question, if:

paragraph.text: the petition filed under § 12-103 of this subtitle did not specify all of the precincts in which the question was on the ballot; and
on completion of the recount, the outcome of the election is changed.

subsection.text: A counterpetition shall be a request for a recount of the votes for the question in the precincts not specified by the petitioner under § 12-103 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the question was on the ballot in one county, the counterpetition shall be filed in that county.
If the question was on the ballot in more than one county, the counterpetition shall be filed with the State Board.

subsection.text: The petition shall be filed within 2 days of the determination under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall promptly notify each appropriate local board of a counterpetition that is filed with the State Board.
A local board shall promptly notify the State Board of a counterpetition that is filed with the local board.

subsection.text: A petition or counterpetition filed under this subtitle shall be filed with a bond as provided under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: If a recount is being conducted in only one county, a judge of the circuit court of the county shall determine and set the bond to be filed by the petitioner or counterpetitioner sufficient to pay the reasonable costs of the recount.
If the recount is being conducted in more than one county, a judge of the Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County shall determine and set the bond.

subsection.text: In accordance with regulations adopted by the State Board, the local board shall:

paragraph.text: conduct the recount and certify the official result of the election or question which is the subject of the recount; and
ensure the public’s ability to be present while the recount is conducted.

subsection.text: The State Board shall monitor and support the work of any local board conducting a recount to ensure compliance with this subtitle.
The State Board shall establish a procedure that will allow petitioners and counterpetitioners to request that a recount be terminated prior to its completion.

When a recount is completed, the local board, and when appropriate the State Board, shall correct the primary, general, or special election returns and certificates that were made by a canvassing board.
In this section, “petitioner” includes a counterpetitioner.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each petitioner shall pay the cost of a recount requested under this subtitle and the petitioner’s bond is liable for the cost.
The petitioner is not liable for the costs of the recount if:

subparagraph.text: the outcome of the election is changed;

the petitioner has gained a number of votes, for the petitioner’s candidacy or for or against the question that is the subject of the petition, equal to 2% or more of the total votes cast for the office or on the question, in all precincts being recounted; or

sub-subparagraph.text: the margin of difference in the number of votes received by an apparent winner and the losing candidate with the highest number of votes for an office is 0.1% or less of the total votes cast for those candidates; or
in the case of a question, the margin of difference between the number of votes cast for and the number cast against the question is 0.1% or less.

subsection.text: If the petitioner is not liable for the costs of the recount as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a county shall pay the costs of the recount in that county.

section.text: This subtitle applies to an issue arising in an election conducted under this article.

subsection.text: If no other timely and adequate remedy is provided by this article, a registered voter may seek judicial relief from any act or omission relating to an election, whether or not the election has been held, on the grounds that the act or omission:

paragraph.text: is inconsistent with this article or other law applicable to the elections process; and
may change or has changed the outcome of the election.

subsection.text: A registered voter may seek judicial relief under this section in the appropriate circuit court within the earlier of:

paragraph.text: 10 days after the act or omission or the date the act or omission became known to the petitioner; or
7 days after the election results are certified, unless the election was a gubernatorial primary or special primary election, in which case 3 days after the election results are certified.

subsection.text: A proceeding under this subtitle shall be conducted in accordance with the Maryland Rules, except that:

paragraph.text: the proceeding shall be heard and decided without a jury and as expeditiously as the circumstances require;
on the request of a party or sua sponte, the chief administrative judge of the circuit court may assign the case to a three-judge panel of circuit court judges; and
an appeal shall be taken directly to the Court of Appeals within 5 days of the date of the decision of the circuit court.

subsection.text: The Court of Appeals shall give priority to hear and decide an appeal brought under subsection (a)(3) of this section as expeditiously as the circumstances require.

The court may provide a remedy as provided in subsection (b) or (c) of this section if the court determines that the alleged act or omission materially affected the rights of interested parties or the purity of the elections process and:

paragraph.text: may have changed the outcome of an election already held; or
may change the outcome of a pending election.

subsection.text: If the court makes an affirmative determination that an act or omission was committed that changed the outcome of an election already held, the court shall:

paragraph.text: declare void the election for the office or question involved and order that the election be held again at a date set by the court; or
order any other relief that will provide an adequate remedy.

subsection.text: If the court makes an affirmative determination that an act or omission has been committed that may change the outcome of a pending election, the court may:

paragraph.text: order any relief it considers appropriate under the circumstances; and
if the court determines that it is the only relief that will provide a remedy, direct that the election for the office or question involved be postponed and rescheduled on a date set by the court.

subsection.text: A determination of the court under subsection (a) of this section shall be based on clear and convincing evidence.
This title applies to each election conducted in accordance with this article.
This title does not apply to campaign finance activity required to be governed solely by federal law.

section.text: Except for a candidate, this title does not prohibit an individual who acts independently of any other person from:

paragraph.text: expressing personal views on any subject; or
making an expenditure of personal funds to purchase campaign material.
The State Board shall prepare a summary of the election law that relates to campaign finance activity and provide for distribution of the summary.
When a certificate of candidacy is filed, the board receiving the certificate shall provide the candidate with:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the summary; and
each form the candidate is required to file under this title.

subsection.text: The State Board shall provide to a local board samples of such of the forms required under this title as the local board may request.

section.text: The State Board may accept an electronic signature for any form, document, report, or affidavit required by the State Board under this title.
Unless otherwise provided by law, this subtitle applies to all campaign finance activity associated with an election under this article.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise expressly authorized by law, all campaign finance activity for an election under this article shall be conducted through a campaign finance entity.
An individual may not file a certificate of candidacy until the individual establishes, or causes to be established, an authorized political committee.

section.text: Each campaign finance entity shall comply with the reporting requirements of Subtitle 3 of this title.

subsection.text: This section applies to a political committee other than a political club.
A political committee may not receive or disburse money or any other thing of value unless the political committee is established in accordance with the requirements of this section.
To establish a political committee:

paragraph.text: a chairman and a treasurer shall be appointed on a form that the State Board prescribes and that is signed by the chairman and treasurer and includes:

subparagraph.text: the residence addresses of the chairman and the treasurer;
if the chairman and treasurer affirmatively consent to receiving notice under this title only by electronic mail, the electronic mail address of the chairman and the treasurer; and
the information required by § 13–208 of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: the form shall be filed with the board where the political committee is required to file campaign finance reports.

The chairman or treasurer of a political committee shall notify the State Board of a change in the residence address of the chairman or treasurer no later than 21 days before the day on which the political committee’s next campaign finance report is due under § 13–309 of this title.

The chairman or treasurer of a political committee shall notify the State Board of a change in the electronic mail address of the chairman or treasurer by the date specified in paragraph (3) of this subsection if the chairman and treasurer of the political committee have affirmatively consented to receiving notice under this title only by electronic mail.

A chairman or treasurer of a political committee may resign by completing a resignation form that the State Board prescribes and filing the form with the board where the political committee was established.
If a vacancy occurs in the office of chairman or the office of treasurer, the political committee promptly shall appoint a new chairman or treasurer in accordance with this section.

subsection.text: This section applies to a political committee other than a political club.
A political committee shall provide, with the filing required by § 13-207(c) of this subtitle, a statement of organization that includes its name and a statement of purpose.
The statement of purpose shall specify:

paragraph.text: each candidate or ballot question, if any, that the political committee was formed to promote or defeat;
the identity of each special interest, including any business or occupation, that the organizers of or contributors to the political committee have in common; and
whether the political committee will participate in presidential, gubernatorial, Baltimore City, or multiple elections.
A political committee may not use a name that is intended or operates to deceive people as to the political committee’s true nature or character.
A political committee established by and for a single candidate shall disclose within the political committee’s name the name of the candidate.
A political committee sponsored by or affiliated with another entity or group shall identify within the political committee’s name the other entity or group.

subsection.text: A change in the information reported under this section shall be disclosed in the campaign finance report next filed by the political committee.
Two or more candidates who have established separate campaign finance entities may form a slate.
After establishing a campaign finance entity in accordance with § 13-202(b) of this subtitle, a candidate may join a slate.

paragraph.text: To join a slate, a candidate shall file a written notice with the State Board.
The notice shall specify:

subparagraph.text: the name of the slate that the candidate has joined; and
the date on which the candidate joined the slate.

subsection.text: In this section, “lobbyist” means a regulated lobbyist as described in the State Government Article.
A lobbyist, or person acting on behalf of a lobbyist, may be subject to the limitations on campaign finance activity prescribed in the State Government Article.

section.text: An individual may appoint a campaign manager by:

paragraph.text: completing a form that the State Board prescribes and that includes the name and address of that campaign manager; and
filing the form with the board where the individual is required to file a certificate of candidacy.

subsection.text: The responsible officers of a campaign finance entity are jointly and severally responsible for filing all campaign finance reports in full and accurate detail and for all other actions of the entity.
Notice shall be provided to a campaign finance entity by serving the responsible officers.
Each chairman, treasurer, and campaign manager shall be a registered voter of the State.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a candidate may not act:

subparagraph.text: as the treasurer of a campaign finance entity of the candidate; or
with respect to any other campaign finance entity:

sub-subparagraph.text: as the campaign manager or treasurer; or
in any other position that exercises general overall responsibility for the conduct of the entity.

subparagraph.text: An incumbent member of a central committee who is a candidate for election to party office may act as the treasurer of that central committee.

With respect to any campaign finance entity other than the candidate’s own campaign finance entity, a candidate for delegate to the Democratic National Convention or a candidate for delegate to the Republican National Convention may act:

sub-subparagraph.text: as the campaign manager or treasurer; or
in any other position that exercises general overall responsibility for the conduct of the entity.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the chairman, treasurer, or campaign manager of a campaign finance entity may serve as the chairman, treasurer, or campaign manager of another campaign finance entity.
All assets received by or on behalf of a campaign finance entity shall be:

paragraph.text: delivered to the treasurer; and
maintained by the treasurer for the purposes of the campaign finance entity.
Assets of a campaign finance entity may be disbursed only:

subparagraph.text: if they have passed through the hands of the treasurer; and
in accordance with the purposes of the entity.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 13–220(b)(2) and (c) of this subtitle and except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the treasurer shall make all disbursements for the campaign finance entity.

subsection.text: The treasurer of a State or county central committee of a political party may not make any disbursement of the central committee’s assets, or incur any liability on its behalf, without authority and direction from the chairman of the central committee.

paragraph.text: If the treasurer of a campaign finance entity is temporarily unable to perform the duties of the office, the chairman of the campaign finance entity may make a disbursement on behalf of the campaign finance entity in the same manner as the treasurer.

If the chairman makes a disbursement under this subsection, within 7 days after making the disbursement, the chairman shall submit a report to the treasurer for the account book of the campaign finance entity, including:

subparagraph.text: a statement of the expenditure made under the authority of the chairman;
the name and address of the person to whom the expenditure was made;
the purpose for which the expenditure was made; and
a copy of the receipt for the expenditure that was made.

paragraph.text: A chairman who is a candidate may not make a disbursement for a campaign finance entity.
Each campaign finance entity shall designate one or more campaign accounts.
Each designated campaign account shall:

subparagraph.text: be in a financial institution; and
be registered in a manner that identifies it as the account of a campaign finance entity.

paragraph.text: A campaign finance entity shall deposit all funds received in a designated campaign account.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection and subsection (c) of this section, a campaign finance entity may not directly or indirectly make a disbursement except from a campaign account designated under subsection (a) of this section.
A campaign finance entity, or a person authorized by the campaign finance entity, may pay an expense of the campaign finance entity from funds other than a campaign account if:

subparagraph.text: the expense is supported by a receipt that is provided to the campaign finance entity; and

the campaign finance entity reimburses the person who paid the expense from the campaign account and reports the expense as an expenditure of the campaign finance entity in accordance with Subtitle 3 of this title.

paragraph.text: A campaign finance entity may maintain a petty cash fund.
The campaign finance entity shall maintain a separate account book for the petty cash fund.
The petty cash fund:

subparagraph.text: may not exceed $250 at any time; and
may be replenished only by check from a campaign account designated under subsection (a) of this section.

paragraph.text: Not more than $25 may be disbursed from the petty cash fund in a primary or general election to a single recipient.
Each petty cash expenditure shall be supported by a receipt and reported by category on the appropriate campaign finance report.
This subsection does not authorize an expenditure that otherwise is unlawful under this article.
A campaign finance entity may make a disbursement only by:

subparagraph.text: check; or
an electronic method that the State Board authorizes by regulation.

paragraph.text: An electronic method of making a disbursement that the State Board authorizes under this subsection shall ensure that:

subparagraph.text: the identity of the person making the disbursement may be verified;
the transaction is secure; and
there is an adequate record of the transaction.

paragraph.text: The treasurer of a campaign finance entity shall keep a detailed and accurate account book of all assets received, expenditures made, and obligations incurred by or on behalf of the entity.
Except as provided in § 13–240 of this subtitle, as to each asset received or expenditure made, the account book shall state:

subparagraph.text: its amount or value;
the date of the receipt or expenditure;
the name and address of the person from whom the asset was received or to whom the expenditure was made; and
a description of the asset received or the purpose for which the expenditure was made.

To the extent practicable, the treasurer of a campaign finance entity shall record the occupation and employer of an individual who makes contributions to the campaign finance entity in a cumulative amount of $500 or more during an election cycle.
The State Board shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: promptly provide notice to the treasurer of a campaign finance entity if a contributor included on a campaign finance report submitted by the treasurer has made contributions to the campaign finance entity in a cumulative amount of $500 or more during the election cycle; and

require a standard response that a treasurer shall include in the campaign finance report if a contributor does not supply the information required concerning the contributor’s occupation and employer.

paragraph.text: Each expenditure made from a campaign account shall be supported by a receipt.

subsection.text: The account books and related records of a campaign finance entity shall be preserved until the earlier of:

paragraph.text: 10 years after the creation of an account book entry or related record; or
2 years after the campaign finance entity files a final campaign finance report under Subtitle 3 of this title.

By the next deadline for filing a campaign finance report after receiving a contribution specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a treasurer shall issue a campaign contribution receipt on the form that the State Board prescribes.
A campaign contribution receipt shall be mailed or delivered to each person who:

subparagraph.text: makes one or more contributions, other than the purchase of tickets for a campaign event, in the cumulative amount of $51 or more; or
purchases one or more tickets for a campaign event:

sub-subparagraph.text: at a cost of $51 or more per ticket; or
in the cumulative amount of $251 or more.

paragraph.text: At the request of a contributor, a treasurer shall issue a campaign contribution receipt for any other contribution.
A campaign contribution receipt issued under this section is evidence of the contribution.

subsection.text: The information from a campaign contribution receipt shall be included in the campaign finance report filed by the treasurer under this title.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, contributions may be made only in accordance with this Part V of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The limits on contributions in this section do not apply to:

paragraph.text: a contribution to a ballot issue committee; or
those contributions defined as transfers.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, a person may not, either directly or indirectly, in an election cycle make aggregate contributions in excess of:

paragraph.text: $4,000 to any one campaign finance entity; or
$10,000 to all campaign finance entities.
Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, a central committee of a political party may make aggregate in–kind contributions during an election cycle that are not in excess of:

subparagraph.text: for a State central committee, $1 for every two registered voters in the State; and
for a local central committee, $1 for every two registered voters in the county.

paragraph.text: For the purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, the number of registered voters is determined, regardless of party affiliation, as of the first day of the election cycle.

subsection.text: The limit on contributions to the campaign finance entity of a candidate applies regardless of the number of offices sought by the candidate or campaign finance entities formed to support the candidate.
Contributions by a corporation and any wholly owned subsidiary of the corporation, or by two or more corporations owned by the same stockholders, shall be considered as being made by one contributor.
In this section, a “campaign finance entity” includes a nonfederal out-of-state political committee.
The limit on transfers set forth in subsection (c) of this section does not apply to a transfer:

paragraph.text: by a campaign finance entity to a ballot issue committee; and
between or among:

subparagraph.text: political committees that are State or local central committees of the same political party;
a slate and the campaign finance entities of its members; and
the campaign finance entities of a candidate.

subsection.text: During an election cycle, a campaign finance entity may not directly or indirectly make transfers in a cumulative amount of more than $6,000 to any one other campaign finance entity.

paragraph.text: All affiliated campaign finance entities are treated as a single entity in determining:

subparagraph.text: the amount of transfers made by a campaign finance entity; and
the amount of transfers received by a campaign finance entity.

paragraph.text: Campaign finance entities are deemed to be affiliated if they:

subparagraph.text: are organized and operated in coordination and cooperation with each other; or
otherwise conduct their operations and make their decisions relating to transfers and other contributions under the control of the same individual or entity.

subsection.text: The limit on transfers to the campaign finance entities of a candidate prescribed in subsection (c) of this section applies regardless of the number of offices sought by the candidate.

section.text: A political action committee that makes a transfer to the campaign finance entity of a candidate or to a slate shall:

paragraph.text: display its official name, as filed with the State Board under this subtitle, in a prominent place on the face of the check by which the funds are transferred; and
include in a prominent place on the face of the check the words “political action committee” or the notation “PAC”, to indicate that the transferor is a political action committee.

section.text: A transfer is not allowed if it is intended to conceal the source of the funds or the intended recipient.

subsection.text: A loan to a campaign finance entity is considered a contribution in the amount of the outstanding principal balance of the loan unless:

paragraph.text: the loan is from a financial institution or other entity in the business of making loans; or
the loan is to the campaign finance entity of a candidate and:

subparagraph.text: repayment of the loan is personally guaranteed by the candidate; and
the election cycle immediately following the election cycle in which the loan was made has not ended.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (c)(2) of this section, uncharged interest on a loan is a contribution.

Uncharged interest is the amount by which, during a reporting period, the interest actually charged on the loan is less than the interest on the loan computed at the prime rate applicable on the day the loan was made.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the terms of a loan to a campaign finance entity shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
include the lender’s name, address, and signature;
state the schedule for repayment of the loan;
state the interest rate of the loan; and
be attached to the campaign finance report required of the entity under Subtitle 3 of this title for the reporting period during which the loan was made.
A loan by a candidate or the candidate’s spouse to a campaign finance entity of the candidate is not required to comply with paragraph (1) of this subsection.
Unless a loan by a candidate or the candidate’s spouse to a campaign finance entity of the candidate complies with paragraph (1) of this subsection:

sub-subparagraph.text: the loan may not accrue interest;
any interest foregone on the loan is not a contribution under subsection (b) of this section; and
the campaign finance entity is not subject to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: § 13-310(a) and (b) of this title so long as the loan has an outstanding principal balance; and

paragraph.text: A loan may not be made to a campaign finance entity of a candidate, or accepted on behalf of the entity, without the express written consent of the candidate.
The written consent of the candidate constitutes the personal guarantee of the candidate for repayment of the loan only if the document expressly so provides.
A copy of the candidate’s written consent shall be:

subparagraph.text: furnished to the lender when the loan is made; and
attached to the campaign finance report required of the entity under Subtitle 3 of this title for the reporting period during which the loan was made.

paragraph.text: Contributions or loans to a campaign finance entity of a candidate from the personal funds of the candidate or the candidate’s spouse are not subject to the contribution limits under § 13-226 of this subtitle.
Expenditures from personal funds by the candidate or the candidate’s spouse for personal expenses of the candidate for filing fees, telecommunication services, travel, and food are not contributions.

subsection.text: A contribution or loan to a campaign finance entity of a candidate by the candidate or the candidate’s spouse shall pass through the hands of the treasurer of the entity and be reported in accordance with Subtitle 3 of this title.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a contribution is attributable to the election cycle in which it is received.
A contribution by check is attributable to the election cycle in which the check is issued.

section.text: This Part V of this subtitle does not affect the right of an individual to:

paragraph.text: volunteer the individual’s time or, for transportation incident to an election, personal vehicle; or
pay reasonable legal expenses associated with maintaining or contesting the results of an election.

subsection.text: A contribution of money may be made only by:

paragraph.text: check;
credit card;
cash, if the contribution does not exceed $100; or
an electronic method that the State Board authorizes by regulation.

subsection.text: An electronic method of making a contribution that the State Board authorizes under this section shall ensure that:

paragraph.text: the identity of the person making the contribution may be verified;
the transaction is secure; and
there is an adequate record of the transaction.

subsection.text: This section applies to the following officials:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Lieutenant Governor;
the Attorney General;
the Comptroller; and
a member of the General Assembly.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) or (d) of this section, during a regular session of the General Assembly an official described in subsection (a) of this section, or a person acting on behalf of the official, may not, as to a candidate for federal, State, or local office, or a campaign finance entity of the candidate or any other campaign finance entity organized under this title and operated in coordination with a candidate:

paragraph.text: receive a contribution;
conduct a fund-raising event;
solicit or sell a ticket to a fund-raising event; or
deposit or use any contribution of money that was not deposited prior to the session.

subsection.text: An official described in subsection (a) of this section, or a person acting on behalf of the official, is not subject to this section when engaged in activities solely related to the official’s election to an elective federal or local office for which the official is a filed candidate.

Under the Public Financing Act, a gubernatorial ticket, during the year of the election only, may accept eligible private contributions and any disbursement of funds by the State Board that is based on the eligible private contributions.

paragraph.text: As to a violation of this section, the campaign finance entity of the official in violation is liable for a civil penalty as provided in this subsection.
The State Board, represented by the State Prosecutor, may institute a civil action in the circuit court for any county seeking the civil penalty provided in this subsection.
A campaign finance entity that receives a contribution as a result of the violation shall:

subparagraph.text: refund the contribution to the contributor; and
pay a civil penalty that equals the sum of $1,000 plus the amount of the contribution.

section.text: An entity that at any time during an election cycle derives the majority of its operating funds from the State may not make a contribution to any campaign finance entity during that election cycle.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Own” has the meaning stated in § 9–1A–01 of the State Government Article.
“Video lottery facility” has the meaning stated in § 9–1A–01 of the State Government Article.
“Video lottery operation license” has the meaning stated in § 9–1A–01 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: This section applies to the following persons:

paragraph.text: an applicant for a video lottery operation license;
a holder of a video lottery operation license; or
a person who owns an interest in the operation of a video lottery facility in this State.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to gaming activity that an eligible organization is authorized to conduct under the Criminal Law Article.
A person subject to this section may not, directly or indirectly, make a contribution to:

paragraph.text: the campaign finance entity of a candidate for any nonfederal public office in the State; or
any other campaign finance entity organized in support of a candidate for any nonfederal public office in the State.

section.text: Except as provided in § 13-240 of this subtitle, if a campaign finance entity receives a contribution from an anonymous source, the campaign finance entity:

paragraph.text: may not use the contribution for any purpose; and
shall remit the contribution to the State Treasurer.

subsection.text: This section applies to a spin or chance on a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune that is authorized under the laws of this State to operate at a campaign fund-raising event.

Notwithstanding § 13-239 of this subtitle or any other law that prohibits an anonymous contribution, a political committee may accept money received from the sale of a spin or chance, and need not identify the individual purchaser in its account book, if:

paragraph.text: the account book of the political committee includes:

subparagraph.text: the net amount received by the political committee at the event at which the sale was made; and
the name and address of each individual who attended the event;

paragraph.text: no spin or chance is sold at the event for more than $2;
the net income of the sponsoring political committee from spins and chances at the event does not exceed $1,500 in a 24-hour period; and
the total receipts of the sponsoring political committee from spins and chances in that election do not exceed $2,500.

subsection.text: If a political committee raises funds in excess of a limit specified in this section, the political committee shall:

paragraph.text: donate the excess to a charity of its choice; or
identify in its account book the amount received from each individual who purchased a spin or chance.

subsection.text: The State Board shall adopt regulations to implement this section.
An employer may establish a program for collecting from employees by means of payroll deductions voluntary contributions to one or more campaign finance entities selected by the employer.

Periodic contributions collected by payroll deductions under a program established under subsection (a) of this section shall be combined and accumulated in a segregated escrow account maintained solely for that purpose.
An employer shall keep detailed and accurate records of each payroll deduction made under subsection (a) of this section, including:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the contributor;
the date on which the contribution is withheld;
the amount of the contribution; and
the disposition of the contribution.

subsection.text: Within 3 months after withholding a contribution under this section, the employer shall transmit the contribution to the appropriate campaign finance entity, together with the information recorded under subsection (c)(1), (2), and (3) of this section.
In soliciting an employee to make a contribution to a campaign finance entity by payroll deduction, an employer shall inform the employee of:

paragraph.text: the political purposes of the campaign finance entity; and
the employee’s right to refuse to contribute to the campaign finance entity without reprisal.

subsection.text: An employer may not receive or use money or anything of value under this section if it is obtained:

paragraph.text: by actual or threatened:

subparagraph.text: physical force;
job discrimination; or
financial reprisal; or

paragraph.text: as:

subparagraph.text: a result of a commercial transaction; or
dues, fees, or other assessment required as a condition of membership in a labor organization or employment.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Affiliated political action committee” means a political action committee affiliated with an employee membership entity.
“Employee membership entity” means an organization whose membership includes employees of the employer.

subsection.text: If an employer withholds from employees by payroll deduction the employees’ dues to an employee membership entity:

paragraph.text: the employee also may make contributions by payroll deduction to one or more affiliated political action committees selected by the employee; and
the employer shall collect the contributions and transmit them to the employee membership entity designated by the employee in accordance with the requirements of subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: Periodic contributions collected by payroll deductions pursuant to a program established under subsection (b) of this section shall be:

paragraph.text: combined and accumulated in a segregated escrow account maintained solely for that purpose; and
transmitted to the employee membership entity within 30 days of being withheld, together with the information required under subsection (d)(1) through (4) of this section.

subsection.text: An affiliated political action committee, in conjunction with its employee membership entity and the employer, shall keep detailed and accurate records of each contribution under subsection (b) of this section, including:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the contributor;
the date on which the contribution was made;
the amount of the contribution;
the name of the affiliated political action committee designated by the employee to receive the contribution; and
the date on which the contribution was received by the employee membership entity and the affiliated political action committee.
Within 30 days after it receives a contribution under subsection (c) of this section, the employee membership entity shall transmit the contribution:

subparagraph.text: to its affiliated political action committee; or

if a contribution is designated for a political action committee affiliated with a State or local chapter of the employee membership entity, to the State or local chapter of the employee membership entity.

paragraph.text: Within 5 days after it receives a contribution under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, the State or local chapter of the employee membership entity shall transmit the contribution to its affiliated political action committee.

An employee membership entity, including a State or local chapter, that transfers contributions in accordance with paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection shall include the information recorded under subsection (d) of this section that is received from the employer.

subsection.text: An employer, employee membership entity, or affiliated political action committee, may not solicit, receive, or use employee contributions in a manner that would be prohibited under § 13–241(e) and (f) of this subtitle if performed by an employer.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Membership entity” means an organization that collects dues from its members.
“Affiliated political action committee” means a political action committee affiliated with a membership entity.

subsection.text: A membership entity may establish a program for periodically collecting from its members and accumulating voluntary contributions by the members to an affiliated political action committee if those contributions are collected together with:

paragraph.text: membership dues invoiced and collected by the membership entity; or
contributions by the members to a political action committee established under federal law, if that political action committee is also affiliated with the membership entity.

subsection.text: A membership entity shall keep detailed and accurate records of each contribution received under subsection (b) of this section, including:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the contributor;
the date on which the contribution is withheld;
the amount of the contribution; and
the disposition of the contribution.

subsection.text: Within 30 days after being received, a contribution under this section shall be transmitted by the membership entity, with the information recorded under subsection (c)(1), (2), and (3) of this section, to its affiliated political action committee.

In soliciting a member, by joint invoice for membership dues or for a contribution to an affiliated federal political action committee, to make a contribution to its affiliated political action committee, a membership entity shall inform the member of:

paragraph.text: the political purposes of the affiliated political action committee; and
the member’s right to refuse to contribute to the political action committee without reprisal.

subsection.text: An employee membership entity or its affiliated political action committee entity may not receive or use money or anything of value under this section if it is obtained:

paragraph.text: by actual or threatened:

subparagraph.text: physical force;
membership discrimination; or
financial or professional reprisal; or

paragraph.text: as dues, fees, or other assessment required as a condition of membership.

subsection.text: In this section, “walk-around services” means the following activities if performed for money while the polls are open:

paragraph.text: distributing campaign material;
stationing a person, including oneself, or an object in the path of a voter;
electioneering or canvassing as described in § 16-206 of this article;
communicating in any other manner a voting preference or choice; or
performing any other service as a poll worker or distributor of sample ballots.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: meals, beverages, and refreshments served to campaign workers;
salaries of regularly employed personnel in campaign headquarters;
media advertising, including newspaper, radio, television, billboard, or aerial advertising;
rent and regular office expenses; or
the cost of telephoning voters or transporting voters to and from polling places.

A campaign finance entity, or a person acting on its behalf, may not at any time, directly or indirectly, pay or incur an obligation to pay, and a person may not, directly or indirectly, receive any money or thing of value, for a political endorsement.

subparagraph.text: A campaign finance entity, or a person acting on its behalf, that pays any person for walk-around services shall make all payments by check from a campaign account designated under § 13-220(a) of this subtitle.
All payments made under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall be reported in accordance with § 13-304 of this title.

section.text: A person who claims that money is due from a campaign finance entity shall present a claim for payment to the treasurer or subtreasurer not later than 30 days after the election for which the liability was incurred.

After all campaign expenditures have been made and before filing a final campaign finance report under Subtitle 3 of this title, any remaining balance in the account of a campaign finance entity shall be returned pro rata to the contributors or paid to:

paragraph.text: if the campaign finance entity is a personal treasurer or a political committee formed to support a candidate or act for a political party:

subparagraph.text: the State central committee of the political party:

sub-subparagraph.text: of which the candidate is a member; or
for which the political committee is acting;

subparagraph.text: the local central committee of the political party:

sub-subparagraph.text: of which the candidate is a member in a county in which the candidate resides or which the candidate seeks to represent; or
for which the political committee is acting;

subparagraph.text: the board of education of a county in which the candidate resides or which the candidate seeks to represent;

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization that provides services or funds for the benefit of pupils or teachers;
a charitable organization registered or exempt from registration under the Maryland Charitable Solicitations Act; or
a public or private institution of higher education in the State if:

subparagraph.text: that institution possesses a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
the payment is designated for use by the institution solely to award scholarships, grants, or loans to students attending the institution.

section.text: In this subtitle, the provisions that apply to a “campaign finance entity” also apply to a campaign entity located outside the State with regard to all expenditures within the State.

paragraph.text: From the date of its organization until its termination under the provisions of this title, a campaign finance entity, except a political club, shall file a campaign finance report at the State Board at the times and for the periods required by §§ 13–309, 13–312, and 13–316 of this subtitle.
A campaign finance report submitted using an electronic format shall:

subparagraph.text: be made under oath or affirmation;
require an electronic signature from the treasurer at the time of the filing of the campaign finance report; and
be made subject to the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: A campaign finance report filed by a campaign finance entity under subsection (a) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: the information required by the State Board with respect to all contributions received and all expenditures made by or on behalf of the campaign finance entity during the designated reporting period; and
the information regarding the occupations and employers of contributors required to be recorded by the treasurer of a campaign finance entity under § 13–221 of this title.

subsection.text: A campaign finance report prescribed by this subtitle for the campaign finance entity of a candidate is required whether or not:

paragraph.text: the candidate files a certificate of candidacy;
the candidate withdraws, declines a nomination, or otherwise ceases to be a candidate;
the candidate’s name appears on the primary ballot; or
the candidate is successful in the election.

subsection.text: Instead of filing a report required under § 13–309 of this subtitle, a treasurer may file an affidavit stating that the campaign finance entity has not raised or spent a cumulative amount of $1,000 or more, exclusive of the filing fee, and regardless of the balance of the campaign account, since:

paragraph.text: establishing the campaign finance entity; or
filing the campaign finance entity’s last campaign finance report.

subsection.text: The affidavit shall be filed on or before the date a campaign finance report is due to be filed under § 13–309 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: This subsection only applies to a campaign finance entity of a candidate for election to the central committee of a political party that is authorized under subsection (a) of this section to file an affidavit instead of filing a campaign finance report on a date specified in § 13–309(a) of this subtitle.

Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, a campaign finance entity subject to this subsection is not required to file an affidavit under this section or a campaign finance report on a date specified in § 13–309(a) of this subtitle.
A campaign finance entity subject to this subsection shall file an affidavit under subsection (a) of this section or a campaign finance report on the date specified in § 13–309(c) of this subtitle.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Donation” means the gift or transfer, or promise of gift or transfer, of money or other thing of value to a person that is made for the purpose of furthering independent expenditures.
“Mass mailing” means a mailing by United States mail or facsimile of more than 500 pieces of mail matter of an identical or substantially similar nature within any 30–day period.

subparagraph.text: “Person” includes an individual, a partnership, a committee, an association, a corporation, a labor organization, or any other organization or group of persons.
“Person” does not include a campaign finance entity organized under Subtitle 2, Part II of this title.

“Public communication” means a communication by means of any broadcast, cable, or satellite communication, newspaper, magazine, outdoor advertising facility, mass mailing, or telephone bank to the general public, or any other form of general public political advertising.
“Public communication” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a news story, a commentary, or an editorial disseminated by a broadcasting station, including a cable television operator, programmer, or producer, satellite television or radio provider, Web site, newspaper, magazine, or other periodical publication, including any Internet or electronic publication, that is not controlled by a candidate or political party; or
a candidate debate or forum.

paragraph.text: “Telephone bank” means more than 500 telephone calls of an identical or substantially similar nature within any 30–day period.

subsection.text: After a person makes aggregate independent expenditures of $10,000 or more in an election cycle for campaign material that is a public communication, the person shall file an independent expenditure report as required in this section.

paragraph.text: If the campaign material relates to a candidate, the person shall file an independent expenditure report with the State Board on the next date a campaign finance entity of a candidate is required to file a campaign finance report under § 13–309 of this subtitle.

If the campaign material relates to a ballot issue, the person shall file an independent expenditure report with the State Board on the next date a ballot issue committee is required to file a campaign finance report under § 13–309 of this subtitle.

An independent expenditure report filed under this subsection shall include the information required by subsection (e) of this section for the period from the beginning of the election cycle through the last day of the reporting period under § 13–312 of this subtitle that precedes the report filing date.

A person who files an independent expenditure report under subsection (c) of this section shall file an additional independent expenditure report following a date on which the person makes aggregate independent expenditures of $10,000 or more for campaign material that is a public communication following the closing date of the person’s previous independent expenditure report.
An independent expenditure report under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: be filed with the State Board on the date specified in subsection (c)(1) and (2) of this section; and

include the information required by subsection (e) of this section for the period from the closing date of the previous independent expenditure report through the last day of the reporting period under § 13–312 of this subtitle that precedes the report filing date.

subsection.text: An independent expenditure report shall include the following information:

paragraph.text: the identity of the person making the independent expenditures and of any person exercising direction or control over the activities of the person making the independent expenditures;
the business address of the person making the independent expenditures;
the amount and date of each independent expenditure during the period covered by the report and the person to whom the expenditure was made;
the candidate or ballot issue to which the independent expenditure relates and whether the independent expenditure supports or opposes that candidate or ballot issue; and
the identity of each person who made cumulative donations in excess of $51 to the person making the independent expenditures during the period covered by the report.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a person shall be considered to have made an independent expenditure if the person has executed a contract to make an independent expenditure.

The cost of creating and disseminating campaign material, including any design and production costs, shall be considered in determining the aggregate amount of independent expenditures made by a person for campaign material that is a public communication under this section.
The treasurer or other individual designated by an entity required to file an independent expenditure report under this section:

paragraph.text: shall sign each independent expenditure report; and
is responsible for filing independent expenditure reports in full and accurate detail.

An individual is subject to the sanctions that apply to the responsible officers of a campaign finance entity under Part VII of this subtitle for failure to file properly an independent expenditure report.

The failure to provide on an independent expenditure report all of the information required by this section is deemed a failure to file and renders the report overdue as provided in § 13–327(b) of this subtitle.
An entity required to file an independent expenditure report under this section shall do at least one of the following, unless neither are applicable to the entity:
